topic.title: CBRI (ODUk) Packet Format over the Interlaken Interface

body.p: The following figure shows the transfer format used to convey ODUk streams over the Constant Bit Rate Interface (CBRI). The CSI field is under software control and there is no hardware triggered insertion.
Two optional user configurable fields are provided:

li.p: The first field (user specific overhead “A” in the figure above) is 4 bytes in length. When enabled, it is compared to a 4B lookup result indexed by the channel ID. If there is a compare mismatch an interrupt is generated but the packet is not dropped.
The second field (user-specified overhead "B" in the figure above) is 2 bytes in length. When enabled, it operates in mode 0 (2B header channel ID map mode) or mode 1 (2B header compare mode).

In mode 0 (2B header channel ID map mode), each DCPB channel ID has an associated 2B value. The 2B header to channel ID mapping is applied to the 2B value extracted from a received packet, and the resulting channel ID is used for the 4B header lookup and packet transfer toward the DCPB. If the 2B value extracted from a received packet does not have exactly one defined channel ID to map to, then the 2B header channel ID mapping is deemed to have failed resulting in the generation of an interrupt, and drop of the ODUk packet.

In mode 1 (2B header compare mode), the 2B header value is compared to the 2B lookup result indexed by the Interlaken burst control word channel number. If there is a compare mismatch an interrupt is generated but the packet is not dropped.

body.p: User-specific headers are inserted per user payload packet and not per the Interlaken burst word. Typically CBRI packet sizes are less than the configured BurstMax size of the Interlaken, so the custom headers will appear at the start of every Interlaken burst word.
Note that use of the optional 4B and 2B headers is only supported for ODUk traffic. These optional headers are not supported for PIF Interlaken packets.

Use of the Interlaken interface is dependent on the nominal ODUk payload size and the bandwidth expansion required for the user specific and the packet maker header. Consider the aggregate bandwidth of the ODUk signals, the nominal ODUk packet sizes used, the number and rate of the Interlaken lanes, and the headers that are added when determining the throughput that can be achieved for the Interlaken interfaces. The choice of ODUk packet sizes and insertion of all the optional headers will affect the throughput that can be achieved over Interlaken. Limited Interlaken throughput, may in turn, limit the number of line and client interfaces that can be supported for a given application.
The features associated with the Packet Maker Header fields are described in Segmentation and Re-assembly (SAR).
The flow of the Transmit (fabric ingress) and Receive (fabric egress) channel remapping and the user header insertion and extraction are shown in the following figures.

fig.title: Transmit Arbitrary Channel Map and Header Insertion Flow Chart
Receive Arbitrary Channel Map and Header Extraction Flow Chart
